ner_module package

ner_module.config module

ner_module.llm_client module

class ner_module.llm_client.NER(api_key: SecretStr | None = None, provider: str = 'openai', model_name: str = 'gpt-4o-mini', temperature: float = 0.0)[source]

Bases: object

This is the Named Entity Recognition (NER) class.

In this class, we define the methods and attributes necessary for performing NER tasks using a language model. The prompts defined in the prompts module are used to guide the model’s behavior. In addition, utilizing a tool manager allows for better organization and management of the various tools that can be used during the NER process.

The tools manager is responsible for registering, unregistering, and retrieving tools as needed throughout the NER workflow. It is possible to change the parameters of the NER class after it has been initialized.

Is also possible to change the parameters of the model being used for NER tasks using the set_model_params method. To retrieve the model parameters, you can use the get_model_params method.

The chat method is responsible for processing user input and generating a structured response based on the defined NER tasks and prompts. The base_model is used to define the structure of the expected output. In this way, it ensures that the model’s responses adhere to the specified format. The tasks defined the entities to be recognized. These tasks guide the model in understanding what specific information needs to be extracted from the user input. If a tool_manager is provided, it can be used to access additional tools and resources that may be helpful during the NER process. In this case, the tool_manager can be utilized to enhance the capabilities of the NER class by providing access to external tools and APIs that can assist in the recognition and extraction of entities. The extra_info parameter can be used to pass any additional context or information that may be relevant to the NER process. It is directly incorporated into the prompt context.

base_model_selector(base_models: List[Type[BaseModel]], text: str) → Type[BaseModel][source]

Given a set of BaseModel, select the most appropriate one based on the input text.

Parameters:

  • base_models – A list of BaseModel classes to choose from.

  • text – The input text to analyze.

Returns:

The most appropriate BaseModel class.

chat(text: str, tasks: List[str], base_model: Type[BaseModel] | None = None, tools_manager: ToolsManager | None = None, extra_info: str = '', ask_missing_params_with_llm: bool = False, user_inputs: dict | None = None, return_raw_result: bool = False) → str[source]

Process user text to extract structured information.

Parameters:

  • text – Input text to process

  • tasks – List of possible tasks

  • base_model – Pydantic model class to use for structured output

  • tools_manager – Manager for additional tools

  • extra_info – Additional information to include inside the prompt

  • ask_missing_params_with_llm – If True, the questions are generated by the LLM, otherwise use default questions.

  • user_inputs – Dict of answers requested due to missing parameters or additional information.

  • return_raw_result – If True, returns NERResult object instead of just data

Returns:

Processed result as string/None or NERResult object

detect_multiactivities(text: str, prompt: str = '', examples: str = 'No other examples available') → List[str][source]

Detect multiple activities in the text.

Parameters:

  • text – The input text to analyze.

  • prompt – The prompt to use for the LLM. Use specific prompt for multi-activity detection only for particular cases, otherwise use the default prompt.

  • examples – Additional examples to provide context for the LLM. Not needed if prompt is provided.

Returns:

A list of detected activities.

get_model_params() → dict[source]

Get the current model parameters.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the model name and temperature.

health_check() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Performs a health check of the NER system.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the health check results.

set_model_params(provider: str = 'openai', model_name: str = 'gpt-4o-mini', temperature: float = 0.0) → None[source]

Set the model parameters for the NER instance.

Parameters:

  • model_name – The name of the model to use.

  • temperature – The temperature to use for sampling.

ner_module.prompts module

ner_module.tools module

class ner_module.tools.ToolsManager(host: str | None = None, bearer_token: str | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

This class is designed to manage and organize tools for the application. With tools we mean functions or methods that can be used to perform specific tasks. These tools can be called by the LLM agent to perform actions based on user input.

With tools the LLM agent can extend its capabilities and interact with the entire system more effectively.

For example, a tool could include a function to query a database, call an external API, or perform complex calculations. In this way, the LLM call can leverage these tools to perform actions that require external knowledge or capabilities.

IMPORTANT: Each function or tool function that is added as a tool must be commented with its purpose and usage. This is ESSENTIAL for the correct calling of the tool by the agent. In case the function is not properly documented, the agent will throw an error.

add_fn_to_tools(fn: callable) → None[source]

Adds a function as a tool to the tools manager.

Params fn:

The function to add. Performs the same logic of the fn_to_tool_fn method, but the function is added directly in the tools list.

add_tools(tool: BaseTool) → None[source]

Adds a tool to the tools manager.

Parameters:

tool – The tool to add. Is a function or method that performs a specific task, that has been wrapped as a BaseTool using the tool decorator.

clear_tools() → None[source]

Clears all tools from the tools manager.

fn_to_tool_fn(fn: callable) → BaseTool[source]

Converts a function to a tool function.

Params fn:

The function to convert. In this way, the function will be wrapped as a BaseTool using the tool decorator.

get_tool_by_name(name: str) → BaseTool[source]

Returns a tool from the tools manager by its name.

Parameters:

name – The name of the tool to retrieve.

Returns:

The tool with the specified name, or None if not found.

get_tools() → List[BaseTool][source]

Returns a list of all tools in the tools manager.

remove_tools(tool: BaseTool) → None[source]

Removes a tool from the tools manager.

Parameters:

tool – The tool to remove.

class ner_module.utils.ProcessingMode(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enum to define different processing modes for the NER system

AGENT_WITH_TOOLS = 'agent_with_tools'

DIRECT_UNSTRUCTURED = 'direct_unstructured'

This is the Named Entity Recognition (NER) class.

In this class, we define the methods and attributes necessary for performing NER tasks using a language model. The prompts defined in the prompts module are used to guide the model’s behavior. In addition, utilizing a tool manager allows for better organization and management of the various tools that can be used during the NER process.

The tools manager is responsible for registering, unregistering, and retrieving tools as needed throughout the NER workflow. It is possible to change the parameters of the NER class after it has been initialized.

Is also possible to change the parameters of the model being used for NER tasks using the set_model_params method. To retrieve the model parameters, you can use the get_model_params method.

The chat method is responsible for processing user input and generating a structured response based on the defined NER tasks and prompts. The base_model is used to define the structure of the expected output. In this way, it ensures that the model’s responses adhere to the specified format. The tasks defined the entities to be recognized. These tasks guide the model in understanding what specific information needs to be extracted from the user input. If a tool_manager is provided, it can be used to access additional tools and resources that may be helpful during the NER process. In this case, the tool_manager can be utilized to enhance the capabilities of the NER class by providing access to external tools and APIs that can assist in the recognition and extraction of entities. The extra_info parameter can be used to pass any additional context or information that may be relevant to the NER process. It is directly incorporated into the prompt context.

class ner_module.ToolsManager(host: str | None = None, bearer_token: str | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

This class is designed to manage and organize tools for the application. With tools we mean functions or methods that can be used to perform specific tasks. These tools can be called by the LLM agent to perform actions based on user input.

With tools the LLM agent can extend its capabilities and interact with the entire system more effectively.

For example, a tool could include a function to query a database, call an external API, or perform complex calculations. In this way, the LLM call can leverage these tools to perform actions that require external knowledge or capabilities.

IMPORTANT: Each function or tool function that is added as a tool must be commented with its purpose and usage. This is ESSENTIAL for the correct calling of the tool by the agent. In case the function is not properly documented, the agent will throw an error.
